ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: this class was truly amazing and it made me think differently about the world around me
I learned about african-american history and how this has shaped how black people interact in white space. Learned about social dynamics and experiences

This course was very insightful. I was able to develop my research and overall writing skills by taking this class. I will be returning to the material given throughout the semester because it was very informative. The class was a safe place for students of color, specifically Black students, to discuss Blackness and its intersectionality with other parts of life in America. Professor taught in a timeline like manner and it flowed very well.
I learned to analyse situations sociologically and learned more about Black history.
I gained insight into the struggles of Black individuals and communities as they navigate white spaces such as America.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: sometimes the content we had to read for class was a little long so i felt that we never got to have as deep of a discussion. wished the content was spaced out more but may require cutting down

Strength/weakness - the material is often repeated week to week. Up to you whether you see that as a strength or weakness. 
Professor Anderson is an interesting person and has many personal anecdotes relevant to the course matter. But there was limited classroom discussion and the class had a lecture format. The reading is almost too much to complete each week, especially when there's no discussion on it.

Strengths are all of the material that was given and the wisdom as well as stories from Professor Anderson. Weaknesses would be the discussions. Professor would usually talk and share for a long time and then say "Thoughts." By that point every one was tired and or lost a thought that they did have. Discussions should be formatted better and students should be allowed to relate the content to current events without having to "stick to the script."

I would like more structure, I wasn't clear where the class was going or what was expected of us. 
I would also like more opportunities for students to speak.

strengths: the materials and resources of knowledge, including the instructors immense expertise and insightful experiences.
weakness: I felt like the course could benefit from straying from the syllabus a little in class discussions, that way students could feel more invited to make connections beyond the materials on the syllabus.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I think it really depends. This course adds substance and context to a lot of experiences that Black people usually go through. It can get a bit repetitive, but it is very useful when taking into consideration your own life and experiences.

The class was a safe place for students of color, specifically Black students, to discuss Blackness and its intersectionality with other parts of life in America. I would recommend it to anyone who wants to learn about Black identity and it honestly should be a mandatory class for all.
Yes! Especially for other students of color. This course gives you the words and histories to put experiences into perspective-- not just academically but personally as well.
